tweets.text: Motivated by @vgr, 1 like => 2 opinions about community building tools

@vgr 1. Wikipedia Talk pages, where the article content is discussed, are tragically bad.

If I had money/clout this is where I would invest it.

@vgr 2. @discourse >> @SlackHQ but I also understand how writing a forum post is way more intimidating than a chat message.

Setting expectations around this might help conversion?
@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ 3. Not everyone can afford @cannyHQ, but if you're using UserVoice, you're telling your most dedicated users to go away.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ 4. The only thing keeping me on Facebook is the Events. All I want is Google Calendar with embedded comments/discussion.

I literally don't understand why this is so hard.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ 5. Because I was raised Catholic, forgiveness/atonement are foundational values for me.

I have yet to find an online social space which supports this meaningfully.
@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ Gotta focus on work for a bit, but I've got 10 more drafts in an Evernote.
@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ Also, did @Twitter make it impossible to stop tagging people in a thread? I can't figure it out. I apologize to the corporate accounts I've tagged...

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @Twitter Thread continued here:
https://t.co/fPrWT5ZELW

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ 6. Meetup + FB Groups work best when people, with interests/approaches in common, make acquaintances and then use a different tool. Both these platforms fear this and have been exploited in other ways. Thus, the ideal purpose is always undermined.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ 7. Codes of Conduct are valuable for setting a tone, establishing norms, letting people know they're welcome... Not for lawyering. As @codinghorror says, if someone sucks, kick them out, regardless if the reason is codified.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror 8. Codes of Conduct point towards bad behaviour, but I also want a document pointing to admired/encouraged behaviour. A code of admiration? A log of coolness/appreciation?

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror 9. The best Codes of Conduct have examples, like Digital Ocean's and Recurse Centre's. Both were adapted into the Nengo Code of Conduct which is my favourite. https://t.co/MsOu7bXxPK

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror 11. Because I'm a slow web-dev, I still haven't built a website for exchanging game house-rules. But this seems like the least-scary way of playing with social norms and I want to do it more.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror 12. I'm super dependent on community-building tech, like Meetup or FB, because I haven't figured out how to do small talk on public transit properly. This feels important, but I don't know what to do about it...

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror 13. The best event hosting space I've ever had was a conference room with rearrangeable furniture + projector. Probably not profitable, but I would love to pay for a time-share arrangement for that type of room.
@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror 15. Research is less lonely if you do it publicly online. Participate in the @StackExchange related to your field.
@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror @StackExchange 16. A good heuristic for community building/design is "How can we be less like LinkedIn?"
@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror @StackExchange 17. Quora should not be trusted. If your community resides there, even partially, it's going to have a bad time.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror @StackExchange 18. Churches are an under-utilized resource for getting outside of your bubble and organisational tools.

I live in Ontario where churches are chill with atheists, (shoutout to @kevinmakins and Eucharist Church) so YMMV.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror @StackExchange @kevinmakins 19. The inability for ML/AI fuckers to congregate on a single forum should be used as a case study explaining why some communities are unable to meet online.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror @StackExchange @kevinmakins 20. Memes lower the barrier to entry for a community, but they also stunt growth. Reddit and FB never gives you tools to move beyond them.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror @StackExchange @kevinmakins 21. Barrier to entry is important, but so is barrier to maintenance. I can subscribe to an email digest of Julia's discussion forum, thus I'm still a part of it. Staying involved in ML/AI is much more difficult.

If you have a Slack, make a newsletter.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror @StackExchange @kevinmakins 22. Publicly declaring a community affiliation is less scary once you have a slogan.

"I'm part of Applied Rationality because of their emphasis on nuance and mindfulness.

@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror @StackExchange @kevinmakins 23. Don't build communities around goals, build them around approaches.

i.e. Entrepreneurs have the same goal, starting a business, but the approach is more important for unification
@vgr @discourse @SlackHQ @cannyHQ @codinghorror Do Improv classes have relevant tech here?
